metadata.Title: CVE-2019-13224 on Ubuntu 14.04 ESM (trusty) - medium.
metadata.Description:
A use-after-free in onig_new_deluxe() in regext.c in Oniguruma 6.9.2 allows attackers to potentially cause information disclosure, denial of service, or possibly code execution by providing a crafted regular expression. The attacker provides a pair of a regex pattern and a string, with a multi-byte encoding that gets handled by onig_new_deluxe(). Oniguruma issues often affect Ruby, as well as common optional libraries for PHP and Rust. It was discovered that Oniguruma incorrectly handled certain regular expressions. An attacker could possibly use this issue to obtain sensitive information, cause a denial of service or execute arbitrary code.

Update Instructions:

Run `sudo pro fix CVE-2019-13224` to fix the vulnerability. The problem can be corrected
by updating your system to the following package versions:

libonig2 - 5.9.1-1ubuntu1.1+esm1
Available with Ubuntu Pro (Infra-only): https://ubuntu.com/pro

libapache2-mod-php5 - 5.5.9+dfsg-1ubuntu4.29+esm4
libapache2-mod-php5filter - 5.5.9+dfsg-1ubuntu4.29+esm4
libphp5-embed - 5.5.9+dfsg-1ubuntu4.29+esm4
php-pear - 5.5.9+dfsg-1ubuntu4.29+esm4

No subscription required

notes.Note: ebarretto> libevhtp doesn't ship oniguruma regex library since 1.2.15-1 mdeslaur> doesn't look like php uses the vulnerable function

criterions.comment: libonig package in trusty/esm was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '5.9.1-1ubuntu1.1+esm1').
mudlet: while related to the CVE in some way, a decision has been made to ignore this issue (note: 'end of standard support').
php5 package in trusty was vulnerable but has been fixed (note: '5.5.9+dfsg-1ubuntu4.29+esm4').
